Author: Buddhism
Text: Do actions that are unpleasant but give good results and don’t do actions that are pleasant but give bad results.

Author: Buddha
Text: Lead by nonviolence, righteousness, and equity.

Author: Buddha
Text: Actively discern good from evil and choose good.

Author: Field of psychology
Text: Recognize the limits of your knowledge.

Author: Field of psychology
Text: Acknowledge uncertainty and change.

Author: Field of psychology
Text: Pay attention to context and the bigger picture.

Author: Field of psychology
Text: Integrate different perspectives of a situation.

Author: Baltes And Colleagues
Text: Deal with the contradictions of situations.

Author: Baltes And Colleagues
Text: Assess the consequences of an action for yourself and others.

Author: Field of psychology
Text: Balance intrapersonal (self), interpersonal (others), and institutional (society) interests.

Author: Field of psychology
Text: Practice emotional regulation.

Author: Nicholas Maxwell
Text: New knowledge without wisdom can cause both harm and good.

Author: Al-Kindi
Text: We must not be ashamed to admire the truth or to acquire it, from wherever it comes.
Solomon's Paradox: people reflect more wisely on other people's problems than on their own.
Buridan's Ass: excessive indecision between options risks inaction and missed opportunities.
Hedonism Paradox: pursuing pleasure directly can reduce long-term happiness.
Willpower Paradox: people may do things better by focusing less directly on doing them.
Meno's Paradox: one cannot inquire about what they know or don't know.
Polanyi's Paradox: people can intuitively perform tasks but cannot articulate them.
Lottery Paradox: very low odds don’t make an event impossible.
Inventor's Paradox: solving general problems can reveal principles to solve specific problems.
